Award.AwardTitle: New tools for new questions: a multi-site approach to studying the development of selective attention in crib bilinguals

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Language development is shaped by the language that infants experience from families and caregivers. Much of our knowledge about early language and speech development is based on infants experiencing only one language (monolinguals), usually English. However, most infants around the world, and many in the United States, regularly experience more than one language at birth (bilinguals). Research must give more attention to the role of bilingual experience in order to better explain early language development. Bilingual children and adults differ from monolinguals in several ways. For example, bilinguals tend to have smaller vocabularies than monolinguals, but they are better at a wide range of general cognitive control skills. These skills include the ability to attend to one thing while ignoring something else (e.g., pay attention to a person's voice while music is playing), and to shift attention between different objects or events. If these differences are present even in young learners, they might have important implications for how these children learn language. New research suggests that some of the effects of bilingualism may be present even in infancy; bilingually-exposed infants show some enhanced cognitive control skills. To better understand how being bilingual changes an infant's cognitive abilities, the current project examines the processing abilities of infants within their first year of life, comparing infants exposed to one versus two languages. We also compare infants exposed to three different specific language combinations. Specifically, we ask the following questions: does bilingual exposure affect how well infants can focus on words while ignoring background sounds? Does it enable infants to better learn new patterns even in the presence of distracting information? Among bilingual infants, is there an advantage if the two languages are very similar vs. very distinct from one another? To address these questions, the project also develops a new, innovative testing system that enables running the same studies in multiple locations, for improved access to diverse language populations.

Parents, early childhood educators, early intervention specialists, policy makers, and researchers all benefit by improved understanding of the potential influences of bilingual experience during infancy. The new knowledge created by the current project will directly benefit basic research on speech and language development. Undergraduate and graduate student learning and training will be enhanced through mentored research experience at four different institutions. The new testing system will be available for download from a public website, increasing access to and opportunities for participation in research and thus advancing knowledge and scientific discovery. The discoveries from the current project will provide evidence for improving decisions by parents and caregivers interacting with bilingual infants, and will suggest recommendations for policies related to language, caregiving, and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Language development is shaped by the language that infants experience from families and caregivers.  Much of our knowledge about early language development is based on infants experiencing only one language (monolinguals), usually English. However, many infants both in the United States and around the world regularly experience more than one language at birth (bilinguals).  Given the importance of infants’ language experience for later language and literacy development in childhood, and the important immediate implications for parents and early childhood educators, research must give more attention to the role of bilingual experience. 

We explored the possibility that bilingual infants might differ from monolingual infants in their ability to learn new words in the presence of distracting information. Previous research shows that the language and cognitive abilities of bilinguals differ from monolinguals in several ways. For example, Spanish-English bilinguals tend to have smaller vocabularies than English monolinguals when measured on English vocabulary. In contrast, bilinguals are better at a wide range of general cognitive control skills. These skills include the ability to attend to one thing while ignoring something else and to shift attention between different objects or events.  For example, bilinguals might more easily or accurately pay attention to a person’s voice while music is playing. If these general cognitive control differences are present even in infants experiencing bilingual input, they might have important implications for how these children learn language.

Our findings confirmed our prediction that the two groups differed, but much to our surprise (and contrary to previous evidence), the monolingual infants showed better processing. Monolingual infants consistently showed a preference for familiar words over unfamiliar words, but bilingual infants did not.  One possible explanation has to do with accents: whereas studies testing monolingual infants have usually used speech recorded by someone with the same local accent as the infants’ caregivers, bilingual infants tend to be exposed to multiple accents of English (both native and non-native variants).  As a result, the stimuli presented in the lab are a less clear match to what these infants hear at home – and this seems to be impacting their recognition of what they are hearing.  This has inspired our labs to conduct follow-up research testing bilinguals with a variety of levels of accent exposure; if our suspicious are proven correct than this will have a major impact on how researchers around the world study multilingual development.  Although the initial studies we proposed were not feasible due to differences in the way monolinguals and bilinguals process speech, what we have learned has allowed us to approach new studies on bilingualism in a more informed way, and laid the foundation for future work in this area.

We also sought to overcome a limitation in the methods available for studying infant language development. Unfortunately, research directly comparing monolingual and bilingual infants has been slow due to at least three limiting factors. First, it can be extremely difficult to find a uniform population to test (some families have both parents speaking multiple languages while in other families, each parent speaks a particular language, etc.)  Second, bilingualism is often confounded with cultural or socioeconomic differences, making it hard to separate issues of bilingualism from associated differences across populations. Third, both infants being raised bilingually, and researchers with the necessary expertise and specialized equipment, are geographically localized, but not necessarily in the same place; few labs are ideally located to access the populations needed for this research. As a result, strong comparisons between monolingual and bilingual infants, and particularly across groups of bilingual infants learning different combinations of languages, requires the ability to test across multiple locations. Finally, one of the key methodologies for investigating early language processing in infants required expensive hardware and specialized software, that, up until now, have been limited to a small number of laboratories, making comparable cross-site testing impossible.  The current project also created a new, innovative testing system that enables running the same studies in multiple locations, for improved access to diverse language populations.  This is a crucial step forward in beginning to create a way to study bilingualism across labs that controls for potential confounds due to differences in procedures and equipment.

This new testing system is now in beta-testing in a half-dozen laboratories across the United States and Canada.  A number of other labs across the United States and Europe have already indicated their plan to use this software once beta-testing is complete. This system uses easily obtainable, “off-the-shelf”, audio, video, and computer components, and we provide the software itself to researchers free of charge. Having an easily available system for conducting infant speech processing studies will result in greater standardization, allowing for expanded access to the technique and improved collaborative multi-site research projects, and increasing access to and opportunities for participation in research, thus advancing knowledge and scientific discovery.
